title: Civil War Recruitment poster - supporting claim

content.description:
Recruitment Poster for the Union Army, 1860s

The poster contains extensive amounts of text of various sizes.

Only the largest text on the poster is legible. Line-by-line, it reads as follows:

Men of Color

To Arms! To Arms!

Now or Never

Three Years’ Service!

Battles of Liberty and the Union

Fail Now, and Our Race Is Doomed

Silence the Tongue of Calumny

Valor and Heroism

Port Hudson and Milliken’s Bend

Are Freemen Less Brave Than Slaves

Our Last Opportunity Has Come

Men of Color, Brothers and Fathers!

We Appeal to You!

Strike Now!

Small, illegible text appears throughout the poster between lines of large text.
Kean Collection / Staff / Getty Images
The seven columns of small-size text at the bottom of the poster include the names of many prominent African American community leaders, including that of Frederick Douglass.
content.question: By urging African Americans to “silence the tongue of calumny [slander]” and warning them that if they “fail now...our race is doomed,” the poster was most likely making the claim that

choices.label: African Americans were previously unwilling to serve in the same units as white soldiers
white Union generals and politicians were not looking out for African Americans’ best interests
African American women should contribute more to the war effort
service in the war would be African Americans’ chance to prove that they were worthy of citizenship

content.answer: service in the war would be African Americans’ chance to prove that they were worthy of citizenship
